Award.AwardTitle: Mapping the hydrolase-oxygenase boundaries and range of catalytic capabilities in the HD-domain dinuclear metalloenzyme superfamily

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: MIOX is the founding and, to date, only established member of the nascent mixed-valent di-iron oxygenase (MVDO) sub-family. It uses a Fe2(II/III) cofactor to activate O2 at the Fe(II) site and myo-inositol at the Fe(III) site for a C-C-bond-cleaving, four-electron oxidation. A recent paper and our preliminary data on the P-C-bond cleaving enzyme, PhnZ, strongly suggest it is the second example of an MVDO, and our analysis of available sequences and structures suggests that several other proteins belong to this class. The mapping of the phosphohydrolase-MVDO boundaries in the HD-domain superfamily and characterization of new MVDOs will facilitate proper functional assignment, expand the known catalytic repertoire of this new class of oxygenase, and shed light on Nature's evolution of radically divergent functions within a common protein scaffold. The project will likely uncover fundamentally new reactions that will expand the known catalytic repertoire of a novel class of oxygenase that at present consists of just a single documented member. It will yield insight into how Nature remodels a protein scaffold and its metallocofactor in seemingly subtle ways to create markedly different catalytic activities. Thus this project addresses two central challenges in molecular biosciences: (1) functional assignment of the huge number of proteins predicted within the terabases of available DNA sequence and (2) understanding the evolution of new functions within a "superfamily" of proteins sharing a common architecture. It will also provide outstanding training in activities ranging from bioinformatic analysis, to analytical and protein biochemistry, to enzyme kinetics and mechanism, to protein crystallography, to biological spectroscopy. The scientific project will infuse the primary outreach activity, a ~120-participant, biennial training "workshop" in modern metallobiochemistry, with new case studies illustrating important concepts, and efforts to extract such concepts and develop new case studies will sharpen the scientific focus of the trainees.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes that utilize a cofactor containing two iron (Fe) ions (diiron enzymes) catalyze a wide range of chemical reactions, many of which are societally very important. For example, these enzymes catalyze steps in DNA biosynthesis and repair; the conversion of the greenhouse gas, methane, to the commodity chemical, methanol; the conversion of abundant fatty acids into alkanes, which could serve as drop-in biofuels for combustion engines; or they install specific chemical functional groups in the biosyntheses of various antibiotics.

The advances in gene sequencing have allowed for a plethora of genetic information - often of whole organisms - to be obtained. However, the annotation and functional assignment of the enzymes encoded by these genes is very difficult. For example, members of the large group of so-called HD-domain proteins, which coordinate a cofactor with two transition metals, often two Fe ions, are typically annotated as phosphohydrolases, because a few biochemically characterized HD-domain proteins exhibit this function. However, in 2006 we and others demonstrated that the HD-domain enzyme myo-inositol oxygenase (MIOX) catalyzes a fundamentally different reaction, i.e. a difficult 4-electron oxidation using molecular dioxygen as the oxidant, thus challenging the general functional assignment of HD-domain proteins as phosphohydrolases.

This award supported research wherein the boundaries of the many HD-domain proteins were explored to predict which of their subfamilies are indeed phosphohydrolases and which subfamilies are MIOX-like oxygenases or oxidases. The biochemical catalytic activities of a number of previously unkown enzymes were defined. A result was that a previously unknown pathway to degrade a known environmental organophosphonate compound was discovered and explored. Organophosphonates are important in the environment, both because they are natural reservoirs of phsophorus for microbial organisms and because they are used extensively as antibiotics and herbicides. Without the ability of microorganisms to degrade these compounds, they would accumulate as massive pollutants. The identification of a new degradation pathway adds to our understanding of how microbes degrade this important class of compounds to acquire phosphorus and protect the environment from their toxic accumulation. The research also unraveled how a single protein scaffold has been adapted through earth's history to promote very different types of biochemical reactions ? both hydrolytic and oxygenative. In general, this diversification of robust, "privileged" protein structures is a key element of Nature's agility in responding to enviromental challenges arising as the earth and life co-evolved.

The research area of biological inorganic chemistry encompasses a wide variety of subfields, including molecular biology, biochemistry, biophysics, inorganic chemistry, analytical chemistry, physical chemistry, and theoretical chemistry, as well as many different methods, such as biochemical characterization of enzymes, reaction kinetics, a plethora of spectroscopic techniques, and computational methods. Because of this broad range of areas and techniques, it is important that researchers working in this field have a good, basic, working knowledge of many methods and approaches employed in the field, in order to design and discuss experiments with collaborators. Therefore, the training of students working in bioinorganic chemistry is an important aspect of this field. Since 2010, the bioinorganic chemists at Penn State offer workshops for training of the next generation of bioinorganic chemists; these efforts are led by the co-PIs. After a smaller ?trial workshop? in 2010, the Penn State bioinorganic group, the Penn State bioinorganic group hosted workshops biennially since 2012. These workshops typically have ~150 participants and include (i) ~15 lectures given by faculty experts, (ii) hands-on training in small groups in ~20 methods, and (iii) presentation of the participants? research by oral and poster presentations. The centerpiece of the workshops is the hands-on training, in which approximately half of the participants from all ranks (undergraduate students to faculty) served as teachers. During these practicals, the traditional roles of teachers and students were reversed to the extent that undergraduate students taught faculty in the students' areas of specialty. Thus far, the Penn State bioinorganic workshops had ~500 participants (mostly students and postdocs), of which ~50 have obtained a job in academia and who continue to work together. Thus, evidence suggests that the workshops not only play a key role in training, but also in facilitating research in bioinorganic chemistry and help establishing future collaborations among ?workshop alumni? to carry out cutting-edge research in bioinorganic chemistry that will address many important topics relevant to our society.
